{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3483044,"name":"Tetsuya Cox","username":"Tetsu","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/41988e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T03:47:01.341Z","cooked":"

This year I returned to my old team to teach the new students how to program. I have no idea how to teach and don’t know where to find the resources. We also only have about a week and a half until I need to return to college. We use VS code, java, and command-based programming.

My goal is to teach them how to use resources like Google and various documentation for code to write code so they can continue to grow without me.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Hello!

This year I am a senior on my team, and spent the offseason teaching programming! Here is a folder of all slideshows I presented to my team, with the first few weeks detailing Java and the next several weeks detailing robot programming. Hope this can be helpful to you!

https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1_kX-fAHigNTX5xijlTyeXq77tnUtcwUP

Find an open alliance team with the same framework and roughly similar design ideas to yours and show them where to find sample code if they’re ever stuck. Bonus points if you can get in contact with that team. (If you can’t, cheifdelphi is a great place for day-to-day questions too)

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-01-15T04:34:02.766Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":52.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":481836,"topic_slug":"teaching-java-programming-help-please","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/teaching-java-programming-help-please/481836/4","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3483160,"name":"Val","username":"Otter502","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otter502/{size}/245799_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T07:21:29.833Z","cooked":"

There are a ton of resources for teaching the programming aspect of programming. But something I would recommend is also fostering a fun environment.
Make sure people are willing to say “yo I didn’t understand absolutely anything of what you just said”
A huge benefit we had this season was that not necessarily that our new members learned a lot (though that did help a ton), it’s that they actively enjoyed learning about programming and wanted to program.

There’s no one size fits all solution, but here are my main suggestions:

  • definitely check in with folks, ask them if they understand stuff and reassure them that “no” is a completely valid answer
  • be passionate about what your teaching (think about the teachers you enjoy learning from vs those you time out)
  • make setting boundaries a part of the team (like if people are jokingly calling someone else a nickname (ie swerve man) it might be a good time to check in with everyone and make sure that it isn’t violating anyone’s boundaries (even if everyone seems like everyone is having fun))
  • Be sure to teach both the high and low level sides of programming, there are sometimes really intricate / annoying bugs that you fix once and never teacha anyone else, encourage folks to write the S/S of bugs (signs and symptoms), the underlying behavior / reasons, and the treatment (what they did to fix it)
    • Here is our control theory slides if you want some extra resources: Spartronics programming control theory 10/30/2024 - Google Slides

If you have an hour, you can listen to me talk about teaching programming or you can skim through the slides, both of which are posted here:

From 0 to Robot: How to Teach Programming to Beginners General Forum
I presented about how I teach programming to beginners at the 2024 FIRST Mentor Conference in Mountainview, CA and was able to get my talk recorded. You can watch the recording here and the slides are linked here. I talk about the physical items you need, lessons I use, and the pedagogy (learning science) behind why it works. I share stories from my experiences and hopefully leave everyone with very actionable plans that they can implement. This isn’t a lesson on how to program. Apparently th…

Here is an outdated page with step by step instructions that students can follow but you’d need to make a copy and update the syntax: My Let’s Learn Programming GitHub Pages

I really like the structure but the commands and such are incredibly dated.

Just thought this could be helpful so I’ll leave it here, over the last two years I’ve been working with our programming mentor to make an introductory java course for our team, all of it is available online here: 3044 OxBE4 Java Course. I think the functional programming & command factory slides will be particulary helpful, provided at least a few of the students know the basics of programming.

The slides can get a little boring though, so we try to make sure students have plenty of opportunities to practice while learning. We’ve also been working on some more complete robot code exercises which aren’t very developed right now, but you can take a look at what we have (in the folder linked before) and use it as a foundation if you like. That kind of learning would probably be the most helpful since you won’t be around to teach them for very long. The wpilib docs are a great resource for students to familiarize themselves with as well.
Hope this is helpful!
